number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 20, 2015
												3rd person, hack and slash, story driven, action RPG in Lord of the Rings universe, that follows the story of the Lord of the Rings books / movies, yet is presented from a different angle, where you play as one of the three heroes set on a quest to eliminate Sauron's mysterious ally in the north.Story is very similar to the movies, and you meet many known characters throughout your journey, like Gandalf, Frodo, Bilbo, Aragorn, Legolas and many more. Most of the time you can only interact with them in "safe" hubs like towns and scripted cut-scenes.Even if you didn't watch the movies, there's fair amount of lore available through dialogues if you chose investigate dialogue options. I didn't encounter choice and consequence in dialogues, so probably they are straight forward and just there for information, lore and story.Combat is mostly hack and slash, with melee weapons as well as ranged ones, depending on hero. You defeat enemies, find loot in linear levels with some hidden passages and secrets here and there. After leveling up you get skill points you can spec into 3 trees, and stats points you can increase stats with, so your basic RPG elements.You can find, buy or get as a reward different kinds of armor pieces and weapons. I have no clue if you can equip your AI controlled allies, but you can trade with them, and if you play in co-op, it's a good idea to trade and offer items you don't use to party members, as you often find items not wearable by your hero.Co-op is strongest aspect of this game, it's really fun and enjoyable, with great synergy between heroes. Dwarf can be tank or tanky melee warrior, Elf has healing, shields and support spells, and Human is basically archer or rogue damage dealer. All heroes have some sort of ranged attacks and require some aiming to successfully hit enemies.Game offers some side quests and challenge locations besides the main story. You can revisit almost any level for additional loot and XP. Dwarf can collect ore and bash through weak walls to uncover secret areas. Elf can gather herbs and brew potions as well as dispel magically sealed areas. Human however can only gather hidden cashes of supplies, and is a bit dull compared to other heroes.There's decent variety of enemies in the game, orcs, trolls, spiders, humans, wyrms, dragons, just to name a few. AI is straight forward, usually rushing you head on as melee or shooting from range with ranged attacks, bigger creatures and bosses have special attacks and require careful positioning or dodging to not get hit. You can easily fall in battle after couple direct hits, unless you dodge or block the attacks.Environments look good yet lack detail, texture quality on characters is decent with somewhat low quality on environments. Visually game looks similar to "Game of Thrones" game. Voice acting and facial animations are decent enough and sound similar to the characters from the movies, yet I doubt there's any line from the actual actors in the game.For a game made in 2011 it doesn't look that good, and could be much better with serious polish, never the less the story and 3 player co-op makes this game very enjoyable 12 hour experience. With hero switching and story replay on harder difficulties, this game will give you up to 30 hours of "content". I experienced some disconnects while playing in co-op, so it has some network issues, make sure if someone disconnect to not advance in story, and just remake the lobby.Enjoy.

												Chic spin-off of "The Lord of the Rings", revealing the history of the brave heroes who played an important role in the struggle of Middle-earth Sauron."War in the North" shows another side of the coin, which will be introduced to the protagonists of this great game, so similar to the familiar trio of canonicity Aragorn, Legolas and Gimli.History Andriel, Farina and Eradana closely intertwined with the main, which is well known. And this is a huge plus, as is observed a clear link with the canon, but at the same time retain their essential game originality and uniqueness.Gameplay pleases: RPG inherent management retains its form. With this, no one will not have problems. It's pretty simple and universal. Pumping capacity, sales of necessary and unnecessary - it is very important in the game process and at the same time not annoying. The combat system is individual for each of the characters, intended for their weapons with armor have their advantages and disadvantages (it is clearly demonstrated in the description of each species), the level of skills can and should be improved.AI in single coil mode, of course, not always on top - there are times when allies can just hang in place, and they will not move until you dislotsirueshsya at the next checkpoint. But these are trifles.Enemies in general classrooms. Canonical, active merzkovaty and terrible. Ordinary really filthy orcs; Uruk-hai are dangerous because of their size and power advantages; Trolls are huge, but slow and stupid; numerous spiders, goblins and the dead included in the category of those who are disgusted with their large numbers. This is all the awesome games.Particularly pleased that the main characters meet Fellowship of the Ring, and have the honor to talk to them.Musical accompaniment retains the inherent "Lord of the Rings" atmosphere that makes me nostalgic every time.My score: 9 out of 10.

content:
ry 14, 2014
												Terrible brawler, everything about the game is wrong down to the most basic mechanics.Even though the game runs at 60fps with no drops on my system it feels like 25, everything is sluggish and delayed like I'm playing through OnLive. Every movement or action has input delay and recovery animations from being knocked down can take control away from the player for 20+ seconds. Enjoy wailing on an enemy for an entire minute while they make no effort to counter or block you, the enemies in this game are mindless sponges, the only danger comes from being overwhelmed by the endlessly respawning minions as 20 of them crowd you at once. Invisible barriers and clipping issues are rampant, every object and character has an invisible sphere extending beyond them that will clip with anything you get within about a meter of, making judging distance completely unintuitive. Laugh as all 3 characters get stuck in a doorway that looks like it should easily fit 5. It isn't hard to make a brawler, and yet this game fails in every category.

ry 19, 2014
												I got this game in a humble bundle expecting/hoping for something along the lines of Return of the King from the days of old....but nope. Terribly shallow, boring gameplay. Mindless button mashing combat. Forget about combos, just press A for quick attack, or press B for power attack, or Z for weak ♥♥♥ ranged attack. Abilities are so dull that you almost never notice that you've used them. Equipment/loot is just like any other ARPG of this type, except with no flavor whatsoever. Story was cliched dribble on top of hilariously cheesy dialog and voice acting. If you want a solid ARPG there are literally hundreds of better choices out there. This game is bottom of the bargain bin at Walmart, but with half decent graphics. It wouldnt meet the expectations of a child raised in the wilderness by wolves who doesnt even know the concept of a video game. Avoid at all costs

content:
er 4, 2016
												It pains me to do it as a fan of the LOTR series but I'll be giving this game a no-go. While there are good aspects of the game (storyline, LOTR lore, cameo characters and decent graphics for a 2011 game) the gameplay is quite frankly, just terrible. It feels like the developers of the game didn't spend enough time fine-tuning the game and making it user-friendly, such being able to compare items efficiently in your inventory when buying weapons and armor - you do get the basic up and down atk/def comparison but nothing for slots or other stat bonuses so you're stuck with exiting the shop and checking your item again. I found that a real pain as I was constantly changing armor and weapons throughout the game. The game was overall buggy with the AI support characters being ridiculous and getting stuck in certain areas. As I played most of the game single player, it was really hard to make it past certain levels without getting help. Yes, I know it's a co-op game, but the single player option is there isn't it? At least give me decent AI or options to customize their skills or armor!I liked the story and thought the script writers did a pretty good job of working around the LOTR universe and making it feel real. Some cutscenes and story bits were pretty good - until I got to the gameplay. It just spoiled it for me :(

content:
er 26, 2014
												--- THIS RECOMMENDED IS UNDER THE ASSUMPTION THAT YOU PAID LESS THAN 6 EURO ---This game shows 100% why the PC master race hates the consoles so much.Now lets list all the things they did wrong:Character switching: you cannot midarea switch character, now i cannot for the life of me figure out if its just cause consoles are so weak they couldnt implement it, or if someone actually thought it was a great "feature" to have....cause reasons?Inventory management: its just a mess, clicking on a weapon on your character dont mean its marked in your inventory, so when selling or repairing, you better make sure its the right thing you actually have marked, and not what appear logical. (a free punch in the jewels, tells me more than 1 person have sold an item they were using)Dont get me startet on how incredibly weak the gear switching is, if you play solo you have to log out, switch char and then gear up, so unless you can remeber exactly what the other 2 are wearing, it just a massive hassle.No going back: ye gods, how i hate that completely linear console way, where you drop downa a 30cm drop and now you cant go back, its in the top 5 reasons why consoles are the worst.Durability: its just so meh to have durability, and having to repair stuff, yuckCompanions: When you play solo, they dont wear the gear you give them, or play by the skills you put point into, thats just weak sauce.Im sure there are a ton more stuff that i forgot.But when all is said and done, i played the game to the end, and didnt regret it, my ragemeter was just maxed, at seeing that a few core changes could have made this game great, now its just mediocre.The combat is fun, albeit i am partial to blood, gore and dismemeberment, you have RPG elements, and gear upgrading, story and VA is decent.

er 15, 2014
												War in the North delivers a well-paced narrative which was born in the non-canon events of Tolkien's Middle-earth. While Frodo and the Fellowship were dangling from a pitchfork above a kettle, the northern lands were defended by stalwarts (unknown) heroes, of which you happen to be part of. As you progress through the story you'll come to realize that, no matter the difficulty, your NPCs are dull and won't serve you well in dire situations.That's where CO-OP mode kicks in. Secure a Teamspeak server with your friends, form your heroic trio and go kill some of Sauron's lackeys. FOR GONDOR!

It's a great hack and slash, with lots of loot.Pros: -Great Art work and level design-Music is Great-Vocals are great-Story is great-Long game of good action and battles-It's LOTRCons:-Game has a few mechanics with combat that are ok could be better. Just remember ROLLING is your new best friend which will get you out of a lot of annoying situations!-Game crashes are a major issue with this game. I did manage to figure out what was my problem and fix the crashing. I made a GUIDE on how i FIXED my game which may work for others.GUIDE:  


YouTube™ Video: taking the hobbits to isengard 

			Views: 23,694,589		

			THEY"RE TAKING THE HOBBITS TO ISENGARD (not my work)		

-Inventory system is not the best and there is no static placement of items in your inventory-can't replay zones that you currently cleared to find more loot. (if you are playing the game how it was designed.)-some creating private game issues. (after a full pc windows reinstall, all of these issues were gone! )

ry 1, 2014
												This game looks like ♥♥♥♥, plays like ♥♥♥♥, and is just terrible.  Multiplayer is super bugged.  It separated my friend and I when we both clicked on the map to travel to the same place.  We got stuck and had to exit.  The more I play, the more bugs are revealed.  Enemies have the ability to blink and skate around.  Dead things vibrate uncontrollably on the floor.  Potions never drop.  Some parts are extremely easy and some parts are extremely difficult.  There is also this dumb thing where your voice echoes when you're in caverns.Running into Gandalf and Aragorn was not that exciting.  They both had the same stupid look on their face.The dumb bird was useless.  It needed me to use a feather for it to attack my enemies.  If its smart enough to talk, it should be smart enough to see me getting ♥♥♥♥ed in the face by a horde of op terrorist bomber gremlin things.The more I play, the worse this game gets.  I keep fighting the same trolls over and over again.  You have to click each item to repair instead of repair all.  I keep getting separated from my friend.  The characters say the stupidest things ever and Arwen looks pregnant.The dumb eagles should have went with Frodo instead of this random three man fellowship.  We are extremely useless and in no way helpful in stopping the evil Sauron.  The eagles are so op and powerful.  They should have been more useful.

content:
er 15, 2014
												War in the North delivers a well-paced narrative which was born in the non-canon events of Tolkien's Middle-earth. While Frodo and the Fellowship were dangling from a pitchfork above a kettle, the northern lands were defended by stalwarts (unknown) heroes, of which you happen to be part of. As you progress through the story you'll come to realize that, no matter the difficulty, your NPCs are dull and won't serve you well in dire situations.That's where CO-OP mode kicks in. Secure a Teamspeak server with your friends, form your heroic trio and go kill some of Sauron's lackeys. FOR GONDOR!

content:
y 30, 2014
												LOTR: War in the North is.....difficult...to recommend. It's a really fun to play action rpg, especially in co-op, and has some good (albeit visually dated) designwork. The combat is gritty and satisfying. Story and characters are decent, but not particularly memorable. The adventure is fairly epic, and sends you to some interesting places in middle-earth. And now that we've covered the positives, on to the regretable bit: It seems proper quality assurance wasn't implemented or Warner Bros just said the product was "good enough." I've played this game on the Xbox 360 and the PC, and BOTH versions have severe game crashing bugs. It is so bad, that I cannot progress any further in either version, though I did get much further on the PC. WB was apparently working on a patch years back, but that seems to have gone nowhere.I had bought the 360 version used, and the PC version through a humble bundle event. If I had bought it at normal retail price, I'd have demanded my money back. It's a shame really, since the game is pretty fun otherwise. I can only hope WB realizes the full value of good quality control and testing. I get the feeling they just cut the QA department's budget (or the dept. completely) to save on development costs.A real damn shame...PS: So far I've only heard of issues plaguing gamers with AMD GPUs. Nvidia owners might not experience these bugs.

content:
er 30, 2013
												I will start by saying it is a beautiful looking game with good story, alot more money was spend on looks than gameplay, but that doesnt make it a good game when dealing with game breaking issues. The AI on both sides are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to say the least, ranged characters focus on melee, everyone hit box is too big and get caugh up on each other. The controls get glitchy sometimes during sessions but other than that are fine, except the drawf and when he gets explosive bolts, you lose the ability to use the crossbow for normal use. As you level up your regular attacks pretty much compare to your power moves or critical moves late game. In the end I wish they put more money into the programming of the combat than looks.It gets worse gameplay wise once you hold off the siege in Nordinbard, Beleram is not where the marker is telling you to go. The lightning in Carn Dun is gamebreaking. It remains unfinished.

er 4, 2013
												The fighting is great. The story is impressive(I have never read the original). You don't need to collect equipments like Diablo. Although some character skills will break the balance of the game which influences your game experience(For your game experience, you should never or less use those skills), I still want to play second or third times after I complete a playthrough. If the game has more freedom, it will be much better. 动作爽快，剧情丰满（我没看过原著），不需要刷刷刷（虽然有个别技能会让游戏进入“无双”模式，不过你不用或是少用就行了）。即使通关了我仍然愿意继续二周目甚至是三周目。不满的地方只是希望能够再自由点，不过其实已经做得非常好了！

content:
er 4, 2014
												This game is more linear than your school ruler. You move in straight line from point A to point B like a train on a rails. Step fight, step fight over and over again. Pathetic dialogs do not contribute into the atmophere.If you wana kill mobs you better look into Diablo style games. This one looks like an attempt to make a game than a game itself.Whats good: amazing work of artists, Middle-Earth scenery and backgrounds are breathtaking. Too bad you are not allowed to step aside from your rails to deepen into the surroundings.Characters are set but some kind of visual customization is present. Thanks for that at least.Recommeded only for most dedicated LOTR fans, consider it a museum excursion interrupted by annoying fights.If you wana good gameplay you better not to bother.

												LOTR: WITN is an adventure/hack'n slash/RPG game aimed to be played in CO-OP. If you can't recruit 2 more friends to play along, brace yourself, 'cause you gonna suffer. As I said, aimed to co-op, means the whole history is played with 3 characters at the same time, of which you just can control one. The other two, if you don't have anyone to share the struggle with you, will be given to the most annoying/dumb/♥♥♥♥♥♥ IA ever made. This is kinda annoying but if you have friends to play with you, the experience is very rewarding and funny.From my PoV, I find odd how this game was abandoned by the developer. It will not require THAT much of effort to tune this game and adjust some minur stuff.Needless to say, the lore is very interesting and the overall 'RPG experience' is nice (concerning loot and build-craft). I would like more choices to make and not only the illusion of choice. ps: About bugs, I just finished the game with friends, but one of them was not able to save the game and unlock the Heroic Mode. So we went back there to help him. But Agandâur just bugged big time, and my char is stucked in the last piece of land in Carn Dum, without hope to be released.

content:
ber 4, 2014
												Let's make this review as the game is: short, but juicy.The obvious +'s of the game are it's lore, background and story. It plays in the original LOTR world, with the original lore, original characters (you will meet the fellowship, Bilbo, etc, albeit only a few have the original voice actors). The plot and quests are believeable and fit nicely into the original LOTR plot.The graphics are fine. Controls, too, which is a surprise, given it's a console port. Might want to take this as an example for other *coughDScough* games.The Coop mode is nice and definitely upgrades the game's feeling. If just because the AI is horrible and needs to cheat the rules to actually be remotely useful.So... it looks nice and has a nice story? You already noticed what's lacking? Jep, the gameplay.The gameplay itself consists of running through linear levels, picking up loot, chests and secrets along the way, whilst slaugthering pile after pile of enemies with a few 'bosses' in between. Albeit those 'bosses' are often ridicolously weak, with the game's toughest points being the 'defend the gate' style horde attacks.Which fades right into the next issue: The game is too easy. It comes with two further unlockable difficultys, but actually the game becomes only easier on the 2nd run, given you, by now, have a pretty well-skilled character who (if you know your numbers) is built towards synergizing mass slaughter. (Note that me and my mates got too bored of the game to try a 3rd run on the highest difficulty setting, but I don't expect things to change.)As you can guess, inbetween nice (but boring once you know them from the first run) dialogues and repetitive slaughter is only boredome or exploring the map for glitches (floating trees are my favourite). The game definitely does not offer a lot of content.As mentioned above, the AI (at least for your teammates in singleplayer) is lackluster, nuff said.End result? 6/10It's fun to play once or twice, short enough for it'S repetitive melee system not to become boring, but not exactly an awesome game by any stretch. If you see it on a cheap sale (5@ and below sounds good) AND have someone to play it with, grab it. Otherwise, not really worth it.

content:
, 2014
												Jeez, I don't even know where to start. To make things simple, if you can buy this on sale for $5 or less, then I'd say it's probably worth playing if you're into generic hack and slash RPGs. Otherwise, this could have been an awesome reimagining of Baldur's Gate: Dark Alliance or Champions of Norrath but falls flat in so many areas. Combat encounters are loads of fun at first because you're not hindered by the awful AI partners; they can actually kill enemies, revive you, and face groups on their own without your constant babysitting. About 6 hours in (of around 12-14), the beefier enemy types stop reacting to your moves which turns the fun hack and slash combat into a chore of "XXY, roll away or block, XXY, etc," and reviving your AI partners because they don't block or roll. About another 2 hours after that, though, you run into enemies who interrupt your attacks and can stun lock you, so good luck reviving anyone once one of your partners is down unless you're lucky (or play Ranger and abuse his Evasion skill). There's also no sense of empowerment as you gain new abilities and equipment. Even ignoring the fact that most abilities (for even the Lore-Master/Wizard) are just boring power attacks that have a cooldown, they never end up doing enough damage to make them feel worth while as you progress through the game. New enemies are thrown at you in such a way that by the time you're doing significantly more damage, the enemies have double the health they used to.I'm not sure how common the technical issues are (seems like more of an AMD thing), but unless you want to downgrade drivers you can probably expect to deal with an inconsistent framerate that BOMBS for seemingly no reason at certain points in the game. Bugs are littered throughout as well, but I didn't run into anything that wasn't solved by quitting and reloading a checkpoint.I should note I didn't play any coop in the game, so maybe that saves some of the issues with its combat, but it's hard to believe the studio that made the amazing Dark Alliance and Champions of Norrath released this. It could have been so much more.

ry 1, 2014
												If you're a fan of the universe this game will satisfy your needs.The game itself is nothing special. The combat is bland and repetitive, the level design is uninspired, and the game can break on a whim. My friend and I were playing co-op and travelled back to town to repair (the repair mechanic itself was not explicity explained, and we had to figure it out on our own), once we repaired we tried to teleport back to our original position. The only problem was the game only placed one of us in the original setting, while the other player was placed in another map. Its bugs like this that ruin a relatively entertaining experience.I only recommend this game because its one of the few Lord of the Rings experiences to be had on PC, and I feel it serves its purpose adequately enough to warrant a reccomendation. If you're not a fan of the universe its best to avoid this game.

												This game is a lot more fun than initially expected, the mechanics work well and the levelling process is interesting enough to max. The story is compelling though not as much as the serie it is derived from. It plays easier and is more compelling when played with two friends. The side stories are nice and give for a fine additional touch. However the game does not arrive without it's flaws because If played alone (speaking from own experience) it might get repetitve. Creating the combination strategies with up to two friends and trying to complete the hardest modes is what makes the game fun. With a possibly ignorant AI the latter is difficult to achieve. Therefore I recommend the game, however do not buy it just because you are a fan of the series because you might get dissapointed without your favourite heroes being playable and but little references made to them throughout the story. Besides all this I hope you have fun playing it if you decide to buy it.

												Jacko Rating 7.5/10What a hidden gem this game turned out to be!  I bought this game on sale and was greatly surprised and impressed with this LOR Hack n Slash.  Better than just about every LOR game to ever be released apart from the latest one Shaow Of Mordor, in fact although a few years old it still has one of the best Co Op modes if not the best Co Op mode in any LOR game to date.Graphics and sound are average but the combat and team format that you play in (team of 3 which 2 of which can be Co Op) is what makes the game and gives you such great enjoyment.  With a touch of open worldness about it in some parts (especially Rivendale) this path lead hack and slash is easy to pick up and gets you in the thick of it right off the bat.Reccomended to buy on sale and try not to pay more than 10$ to really get your value for money.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 17, 2016
												If you have an AMD card, don't bother, you're just going to have a mess of problems in Chapter 2 and Chapter 8. I managed to get through Chapter 2, despite the crazy amount of frame drops, stuttering, crash to desktops, had to restart the computer a few times, etc. Chapter 8 though. I just can't do it. I manage to get to a part where I'm supposed to find a lever after travelling through a series of sewage pipes under a fortress and the game just freezes up after a crazy amount of stuttering and frame drops. Just not good optimization for AMD cards.The game itself isn't bad. It's a fun action RPG in the Tolkein universe, so I was sold right away. You get to choose one of three characters, a man, a dwarf, and an elf. And you're not stuck with just that character, you can switch off in the main menu and continue from where you left off with any of the other characters. The combat is neat, but maybe a bit repetivie. The graphics are okay, but the character animation is pretty terrible. The combat animation, however, is actually great. The story isn't too compelling but you get to explore recognizable parts in the Tolkein universe as well as areas that have been mentioned but not necessarily explored in the novels or films. Basically, the plot involves the three characters banding together to fight off an evil force to the north while the Fellowship travels south towards Mordor.I should mention the gameplay as well. It's extremely linear. Basically, you enter an area which is counted as a "Chapter", and you continue along a path in that area in Middle-earth until the end of the Chapter. So it's not open world if that's what any of you wanted to know.If you have an Nvidia card and are a Tolkein fan, this game is good fun for its duration. No real replay value though.7.0/10 (Nvidia cards)5.0/10 (AMD cards)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 27, 2014
												Do I recommend playing this game? Yes.What's the catch? Of course there's a catch:STORY: The story in this is interesting, but don't expect some major twist. If you played the Third Age, it's kind of that same setup. Your mission is to support the fellowship by distacting Sauron's forces away from Frodo and gang. You'll meet the likes Aragon and Gandalf, but there's one problem: the voice acting. I'll give Gandalf's voice actor credit, he really tries to sound like Sir Ian, but he just falls short. Aragon's is just awful. It's not to the point where I can't listen to it, but don't be suprised when he sound's nothing like his film counterpart. GAMEPLAY: The gameplay is what I imagine would happen if you took Dragon Age and Skyrim and paid them to make a baby. You've got the run around and find loot off of enemies and hidden chests like Skyrim (Yes, I know Dragon Age has it but I don't have to go find a Rogue whenever I find a chest in this game). The combat itself feels like a mix of Dragon Age, Skyrim, Arkham, and only the slightest hint of Gears of War. You have your two team mates that do somewhat support you unless you're playing in Coop (That's an entirely different discussion) and in a way it reminds me of Dragon Age, except that I have no control over them. It's like Skyrim in that there is no pause feature; you are constantly in the midst of the battle. It's like Arkham in the sense that you have really neat slow motion finishing moves occasionally (Yes, I know Skyrim has those, too, but I think that Arkham's has more in common with the style this game has). When I saw Gears of War, though, I don't refer to the cover shooting mechanic, I mean more of the coop system. Even in a singleplayer game, when you lose all of your health, you will go into a downed position and can slowly crawl to your teammates like in Gears. The constant, "Get on that turret!" command also seems reminicient of Gears to me, also. Aside from combat, you will be navigating a fairly linear world populated with breakable barrels, secret caches, and tons of Orcs. It's fairly simple in that regard. You progress through the level, break barrels for ammo, loot, and coins, occasionally stop at random places to purchase new gear or sell loot, and then carry on.GRAPHICS: I would say these Graphics remind me of Dragon Age 2, particularly in the environment. The way it's textured and modeled just reminds me of it. The ground doesn't look like, say, Halo or Crysis where you look at the ground and think how pretty it looks (I know that sounds weird, but seriously look down sometimes.) The ground looks like it kind of all blends together and there is no distinct place where a rock sticks up or grass ends and sand or dirt starts aside from a bland change in texture on a flat face. The characters, on the other hand, are an entirely different story. The characters look really sharp and well rendered. The clothes flow when you run, there aren't random sharp edges on the character, etc.OVERALL: Overall I'd say this is a neat game. If you like Lord of the Rings or want an RPG that you won't spend 50+ hours running around in like Dragon Age or Skyrim, absolutely invest in this game, but I'd stick to buying it on a sale. This game is by no means remarkable. It isn't going to astound you with its story, blow you away with its soundtrack or voice acting, etc. It's a game that manages to ride right in the middle where you'll enjoy playing through it, maybe play it again with some friends, and then occasionally look at it as you scroll through your Steam library and think how much fun it would be to play Shadow of Mordor which sits right above it.

content:
2015
												TLDR: Third Person hack/slash RPG similar to Dragon Age 2, but set in Tolkien’s Middle-Earth. Melee combat has a similar feel as the first Witcher game where you kind of need to flow from one hit to the next to build up strike power. The game appears to be built around multiplayer co-op, but I’ve only played single-player thus far. WARNING: If you have an ATI/AMD video card you will probably have technical trouble with this game. Big thumbs down for the game breaking bug (near the very end) - 2/10. Would have been 6/10 if the game actually worked.If you liked Dragon Age 2 more than you liked Dragon Age Origins (not many people do) you might want to give Lord of the Rings: War in the North a try. The game is more linear and focused on combat than world-building. This might have to do with the fact that the “main story” is happening elsewhere (Fellowship of the Ring) and you’re just the distraction to help Frodo sneak into Mordor. You play one member of a trio of adventurers at around the start of the first Lord of the Rings novel. Before Frodo, Aragorn, and their buddies start their journey to Mount Doom, Farin the dwarf (melee fighter), Eradan the ranger (archer), and Andriel the elf (mage) are fighting the good fight against the servants of the dark lord Sauron, who are led by a bad dude named Agandaur. Since Agandaur is Sauron’s right hand man fighting the bad fight in the north, your goal is to smash him and draw Sauron’s attention away from the south, where the Fellowship of the Ring are making their way into enemy territory. The game is played in the third person perspective and while you can only play as one of the three characters at a time, you get opportunities to switch which character you’re playing between game chapters. Really though, you should probably stick with one character per playthrough because the game will auto assign the stats and skills of the characters you aren’t using when they level up, and you won’t get much opportunity to customize if you keep switching around. Unlike the Dragon Age games, you don’t control the whole team, just the guy you’re playing. Also, you’re controlling all your character’s attacks as well, not just designating a target.Like many hack and slash action RPG’s you run into a lot of loot and equipment in the game. You pretty much have as many equipment slots as Diablo 2, but most of the gear you find is “non-magical” and can be easily compared to similar pieces. This means there isn’t much in the way of randomly generated loot stats, and you don’t need to spend much time grinding for items. In fact, you probably shouldn’t even buy weapons from the vendors because chances are you’ll just find something better in about 10 minutes.Pros:+Co-op gameplay available so you can go through the single player campaign with a friend or two. Each character has a unique “secret finding” skill that can only be used when a human is controlling the character (in single player, you only find secrets that your character can “see”) so if you have a full team of human players you can find all the secrets in a level. Also, bear in mind that like many squad based games, you can revive your allies if they’re knocked out. So you don’t need to spend too many healing potions if you know your buddy can just bring you back to life at full health.+Decent story that takes you all over Middle Earth (well, a lot of it) and involves some of the characters from the Lord of the Rings books/movies. Why don’t the eagles just fly everyone everywhere? Play the game and find out!Cons:-This is the big one. If you have an AMD video card like I do (Radeon 7850) you will find the game has extremely poor frame rate at many places. I was unable to finish because at the last chapter, the game slowed to a crawl and would crash out repeatedly at the same place. Searching online, this seems to be a problem for a lot of people. My friend has an nVidia GPU and didn’t have this issue.-The “critical hit” system of the game can be fun sometimes but after a while it gets really repetitive. You built up power by continuously hitting a single enemy uninterrupted and eventually you can use a power attack with a chance of instantly killing them. Problem is, this means it takes like 2 minutes to kill many of the more powerful enemies, especially near the end of the game. Also, you only hit one enemy at a time no matter how wide your swings look, so attacking large groups of bad guys is really annoying (the little ankle-biters keep interrupting your combos against the big guys).-Despite how linear the game plays, it’s still possible to miss side quests because many of the quest items are randomly dropped. Cleared the whole area and didn’t find the special quest rock? Too bad for you, play through it again.-You can’t see the enemy’s life (except for bosses) and most bad guys seem to have a ton of life. This is probably intentional to force players to use the critical hit system more, but it means every fight seems artificially prolonged. Should it really take 50 hits to kill an orc?Overall, the game is fun (when it’s working) if you enjoy hack and slash and want to dive once again into Lord of the Rings lore, but there’s a lot of room for improvement. The fact that there are 3 playable character classes is reason for replay, but from what I’m told they’re mostly the same. If this game is in your backlog you should push it back in favor of something better, but it’s worth playing eventually: IF you have an nVidia graphics card. The game’s developers have abandoned the project so the crashing/low frame rate issues will not be fixed. The 90% of the game that I got to experience was sort of fun.

content:
er 17, 2014
												Multiply my "hours on record" by 2 or so to get closer to the real amount of time I've so far spent with this game.Greatly underrated game. While certainly not perfect, it does its job really well of delivering a battle-heavy stroll through really beautiful and atmospheric locations of War of the Ring Middle-Earth, following a plot that is simple and yet of some very respectable quality. Gameplay is straightforward click/key-to-hit combat with a number of abilities based on button combos. While the characters do not always respond optimally, a few hours of play and you'll be more than at ease as you go toe to toe with big nasties. A regular stat & talent-tree based progression with unlockables as well as upgradeable equipment give it the little RPG flavor that deepens gameplay a bit, without complicating things too much or making the game try to be something other than it is: a very decent hack and slash experience.The rendition of all the places we visit is beautiful due to how much personality and distinctiveness each environment has and the characters certainly work well, surprisingly being generally closer to book than film in terms of how they speak and behave, which is really pleasant. The focus on oft-neglected Book 1 environments (Barrow Downs, Fornost, Ettenmoors, Misty Mountains... with a very nice escape through Mirkwood) is also a very pleasant change from the usually inevitable tropes of Rohan and Mordor.While somewhat repetitive as all games of this type are, the game throws enough action and enough variety in enemies (from goblins to trolls all the way through uruks, savages, spiders...) to keep things interesting from the first level to the last. A good bunch of abilities and three quite different playable characters help in that regard.It was never game of the year material but it scores points for being a mostly well done product into which a lot of care has gone, despite its shortcomings and limitations. Very decent gameplay, beautiful environments, high quality music, interesting story moments. I recommend it. It deserves the follow-up that it will unfortunately never get.

content:
1, 2015
												The game feels as if they're just using the IP of Middle-earth for the sake of it (much like Shadow of Mordor). It's as generic as it comes for a game. It might as well have been a Dragon Age game and nobody would notice a difference.The gameplay itself gets fairly repetitive. You take control of one of three characters and do the same thing over and over until the level is finished. You level up as you progress and get better gear (though it feels like they've taken a generic RPG element and just thrown it in). But the other two characters you don't play as also level up alongside you. So eventually they're completely outmatched by the enemies and you need to gear them up. This requires you to actually log out and log back in as the new character... you can't just switch between them or gear them from one character.There is also a part where the game just decides to ramp up the difficulty for no reason. It's a random spike of difficulty out of nowhere. You have to protect a gate from two trolls, who can take it out in about 15 - 20 seconds. Problem is, they just ignore you and run right past you, even when you're stabbing at them. I had to wait until the game glitched and the trolls froze on the spot before I could beat it, because the DPS you'd need to take them out before they reach the door only a few feet away is way beyond what you'd be expected to have by that point.There is no way to save manually, so sometimes you'll waste a lot of time fighting a load of enemies, want to save but you can't until the end of that section, which could be anywhere, you don't know. And if the game crashes (more on that further down), you've wasted all of your time.AI is pretty stupid. If you get taken out, you get a chance for your teammates to help you back up. But half of the enemies interrupt them before they can get you up fully, so you have to wait. Instead of them killing the enemy then trying again, they just keep going in a loop of try to help, get interrupted, try to help, get interrupted, and then eventually die. Sometimes they'll just run into the enemies that killed you, get trapped in them and just keep trying to run at you with no success.But the reason it gets a solid 'no' recommendation is just because of all of the graphical problems. Some levels (like the Barrow-downs) are so glitchy that the game will crash all the time. My own PC is high-end and takes punishment from any other game without issue, it just puts out some heat. But even on the lowest settings, this game creates graphical glitches (weird glowing and static-looking graphical elements) or just crashes to desktop. It's not the sort of thing you expect from a game.Overall, a buggy game that feels like it's just been given a LotR coat of paint and brings nothing to the table that other games of the same type don't do already. A cash-grab that relies on Middle-earth fans (who, ironically, will cringe at the lore-breaking elements, like American accents, a dragon, and constant use of eagles).Edit: I recently just found this in my "Unfinished" section. After loading it up, I remember why. I'm currently stuck in a part called "Carn Dum". It's basically a load of blood-filled sewers. However, the game is not coded well enough to run properly. It crashes every single time you try to just walk through the game. That's all. Just walking will crash it. It can even crash your entire PC, not just the graphics driver, so watch out when playing this game. It's a damn liberty.Steer clear of this mess.

Near the end it was literally unplayable because it was crashing constantly at Carn Dûm, stuttering and it was full of artifacts. I tried many guides with the hope it can be fixed, but nothing helped significantly. And some guides suggested to update bios or install older drivers. Of course i wouldn't go so far and put my self into such trouble for this game. I managed to complete it, by giving my save files to a friend of mine with nvidia so he could pass the point where my game was unplayable.Anyway, despite the terrible optimization, the game is okay, has okay graphics, it's a bit slow with the dialogs. Wouldn't spend money on it though, maybe when it is -85% off. If you have money and nvidia, take it.

content:
er 1, 2014
												While this game eyes great, it does have a lot of potential. However, various things deny that potential. 5 second knockdowns, your companions blocking your way, no flinching upon being hit resulting in just dropping dead, litte logic within the story line and to much a linear way to play.Also, having to choose a single class and the game forcing you to play that class till the end of the game, since all the fancy equipment you gave to your AI companions will be gone when you select them. Making sure that once you change, you've got no way to match the equipment to that level, unless you buy yourself the equipment, which is only possible after  you've reached Rivendell. All in all, if the devs payed some more time upon developing the game, it would've been recommendable and enjoyable. Now it's just a frustrating experience I must add. So, if you're looking for a decent Lord of the Rings slasher, I'd suggest playing the games made 10 years ago, or the somewhat newer Middle Earth: Shadows of Mordor.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												The ever-expanding Lord of the Rings franchise is one that I constantly find to be treading the treacherous line between gratuitousness and sincere narrative expansion. It remains my fantasy world of choice, and offers an incredibly rich setting in which to stage new adventures and exploits of novel characters. Developer Snowblind (known for RPGs Baldur’s Gate: Dark Alliance and Champions of Norrath: Realms of EverQuest, among others) brought us War in the North, following a previously unseen band of heroes concurrent with the events of the Fellowship, much in the same vein as EA’s The Third Age back in 2004.Tolkien's vision was of such wide scope that I have absolutely zero problem with this premise, and could happily see it repeated time and time again. In my opinion the source material allows for a massive degree of expansion, which some games have captured extremely well. War in the North, however, is not one of them.It’s a hack-and-slash action-RPG wherein you control your choice of an Elf mage, a heavy-handed dwarf with an axe, or the quintessentially rugged Ranger. You are tasked with dealing with Sauron’s forces in the North of Middle Earth, preventing his self-proclaimed right-hand man Agandaur from gaining influence while the Fellowship proceeds south. You’ll bump into familiar faces along the way, gaining experience from fallen enemies to acquire new combat skills and purchasing more powerful gear, which can also be found in chests scattered around levels.Progression is simple through the segmented areas, and NPCs offer sidequests should you speak to them in each hub area, usually with the promise of a small reward.As I said, there’s more than enough imagination to go around, but I hate to see the wonder I had instilled in me through reading about Middle Earth abused to shoehorn subpar titles into the marketplace, it really gets to me on a personal level. All the licensed characters are here, Frodo, Gandalf, everyone you’d want to see, but the Lord of the Rings experience feels entirely lacking. The great strength of that mythos is the magnificence of the world; Tolkien's description was so vivid in his attempts to express the beauty and wild danger of the land.Unfortunately very little of this feeling is captured in War in the North - textures and colours are dull and flat even at maxed settings. Furthermore, the lack of detail was apparent to the point where I was having difficulty distinguishing 1080p from 720p resolution, something that is usually night and day in other titles. There was little variation models and level design is utterly uninspired, even over the range of environments that are present. Getting through the game simply consists of ‘kill a load of things, collect loot, kill a load more things, collect loot’, with little in the way of variety in enemy design or challenge.Furthermore, there is very little use of licensed music which was always one of the strengths of Peter Jackson’s cinematic imagining. Instead the score is bland and repetitive, not distinctly bad by any means but certainly unremarkable. On the note of sound, many elements of the game’s story are told through cutscenes; while they are rendered in-game using your character’s specific gear sets which is something I actively like to see, the voice acting is just embarrassing on the whole, with the main cast sounding bored and uninterested. It’s a shame too because the eagle that comes to accompany you on your adventure was cast exceptionally well, being portrayed by the talented John Patrick Lowrie, whom you may have heard as The Sniper in Team Fortress 2, among other roles. Unfortunately the supporting characters generally do not share this fate - Elrond, Bilbo, Gandalf, all of them sound dull, sadly.All that being said, there are a few features that salvage War in the North from the maw of worthlessness. For all the combat was highly repetitive, it was extremely fluid for the most part, and I enjoyed the fast pacing awarded by ‘Heroic Mode’. Essentially chaining blows without receiving damage increases your capability to deal it, which acts a preventative measure for simply mashing buttons, instead encouraging dodging and well-timed interrupts.I also liked the item system - drops from enemies and chests are entirely random, meaning that coming across a rare piece of loot gives a feeling of genuine excitement. Themed armour sets can be collected, and suitable gear elements can be adorned with elfstones to provide additional stat bonuses should you need them. Herbs and other flora can be collected around the game world and combined through a limited crafting system to produce potions and items to aid you in battle, often providing powerful abilities such as enhanced strength for a short period of time.Unfortunately trying to produce an appealing Lord of the Rings game at this point is playing with fire, and I think Snowblind got singed. I do believe War in the North to be arguably adequate as an RPG in its own right, but it falls short of the admittedly very high standard that we have come to expect given the size of the fandom. Pick it up if you want a fast-paced RPG to have fun with, but be aware that no new ground is being broken, and for a Tolkein-esque narrative you’ll definitely want to look elsewhere.

content:
er 30, 2016
												There don't seem to be many detailed reviews, so I will try to write one for everyone. Though I feel it is going to get thumbs downed a lot because I am not a die-hard LOTR fan and I don't kiss the franchises ♥♥♥.The ReviewIts a good game, but I thought there would be a lot more to it. The ending and the entire story really feels irrelavent to the actual story.I was also expecting the story to be much much longer, seeing as how it would play in the timeline of the 3 movies, but instead the game didn't take long to beat at all, or at least not as long as I had expected.This game took me 11 hours to beat, and about 8 hours of that is gameplay, while the other 3 hours is storyline.Seeing as how you meet the fellowship before they depart, I thought you would be a group that played a part in the movie, but were more in the background, sort of like you had a part in the story that the books and the movie didn't show. The in-game map shows all of the locations of the LOTR, Helms Deep, Mordor, The Shire, etc.I thought we'd take part in the battle at Helms Deep, that maybe we would fight some Orcs/Goblins that had followed Frodo and Sam, without their knowledge, as they were about to destroy the ring. I thought we would be able to explore places like the Shire and some of the other major places in LOTR. But instead, you go everywhere EXCEPT those places.By the end, I feel like the War in the North and all of what is done in this game is irrelavent. Like it played no part in the main story, like it added nothing important to it. You have this "right hand" of Saruan, Leader, but I'd think that if he was that important, powerful, and in charge, he would've been mentioned in the movies or books, so adding this enemy seemed pointless.Overall Cons- The gameplay is quite annoying, feeling clunky and based on button mashing.- You can tell the game was built on the purpose of co-op. seeing as how everytime you switch characters, your previous characters gear is changed to a default kind of gear, so you cant set other characters gear unless you are playing as them.You also cannot switch characters as you please, you can only switch between chapters, so you may as well stick to 1 character throughout your entire solo playthrough.- The Orcs all feel the same, like a bunch of brutes, and all take 7-10 hits to kill, EACH. Which makes it frusterating and boring when you're fighting large groups of orcs.- There is no build with any of the characters or their friendship. They are simply 3 travelers who decide to fight the war in the north. There is no character build, no relationship built by the 3, and all of their personalities are the SAME.* Remember how Legolas and Gimili had that funny relationship where they would have a contest of who would kill more orcs in a battle?* Remember how Legolas and Arigorn had a brotherly kind of relationship?* Remember how Arigorn and Gimili had that semi funny moment where Gimili asked Arigorn to toss him over to the bridge at Helms Deep, then said "Don't tell the elf!"?* Remember when Gimili tried to jump across a bridge, that he thought he could make, while a demon was chasing them and when he jumped he almost fell, and Legolas grabbed him to save him and Gimili yelled "not the beard!"?The point is, there was relationships built within the fellowship. Here, there is NONE! No relationship, no friendship build at all! You will end the game not caring at all about ANY of the charaters, except maybe the birds.I was looking for the dwarf to have that battle-thristy personality, the elf to have the wise personality, and the human to have the smart and careful personality. But instead, they all have the same, bland, boring, personality.- Your AI teammates can be quite annoying when they are struggling to revive you or your companion, or when the elf wont heal you when you're 1 hit away from death, or sometimes they will not follow because of 1 single enemy so when you run into another group you'll be left struggling while they sit back with their thumbs up their ♥♥♥ trying to kill this 1 single orc archer that they cant hit or kill and once you are down they will take forever to actually reach you since they are now the prime targets of the group of orcs that just murdered you dead.Pros- Its semi-fun to play. I played it solo, so its probably better with co-op.- Its cool getting to meet most of the fellowship before they leave onto their quest.- The leveling up system is pretty nice, like any other RPG game.- Has NG+ so when you start a new playthrough, you don't lose all your gear or your level(s).OverallMaybe my expectations were too high, maybe my standards were too high, but I am very bummed out about how this game turned out and how it ended and the time it took for me to beat it.I recommend to get this game while it is on sale. Maybe its because i'm not a die hard fan of LOTR and I am not an ♥♥♥-kisser to the franchise, but to me, this game is a MAJOR disappointment, and not worth $20. I bought it on sale, and I think its a good game if its worth $5 - $10. But this game is NOT all that it is made out to be. Its good, and I reccomend buying it when its on sale. At full price? No.Rating: 4/10

												You can consider yourself lucky if your game hasn't crashed while in-game without a recent save.The game(play) itself is good, the combat is enjoyable and satisfying. But with the bugs and crashes, this game is a dislike from me.The crashes happen at random times, and it's annoying if you haven't recently saved the game, as you'll have to repeat again to the spot where you was when it crashed. When you go down, both AI try and help you, therefor drawing the attention of enemies to the reviver, and getting knocked down while being revived. Terrible AI, they cannot navigate very well.I'm on a low-end video card (Radeon R7 240 2GB) and I can run this on Max settings, including Motion Blur, etc at 1600x1200 with decent fps. The mouse movement is terrible, it's jaggy and I can't spin/turn fast without getting confused.It can get repetitive, but at times you forget it's getting repetitive and continue.Gameplay 7.2/10Stability (Bugs & Crashes) 3/10AI 4/10

												Right off the bat, I will admit that I didn't play this game. Because of that, I can't give you a good review. However, the reason that I was unable to play the game was because I was doing so with my friend, while talking over skype. However, the game decided that the best matter of course for this game was to force you to use steam voice chat, because it was certain that steam voice chat was better. There was no setting, nothing that you could change to alter this, so we were forced to use steam voice chat. That was fine, however the game also decided that, because it would "increase immersion" or whatever it thought, that it would change the properties of the microphone depending on the scenery. For example, the microphone would be normal in a tavern, EXTREMELY quiet in the rain, and EXTREMELY echoey(?) in a cave. GG, Snowblind. GG.

content:
er 4, 2014
												You can consider yourself lucky if your game hasn't crashed while in-game without a recent save.The game(play) itself is good, the combat is enjoyable and satisfying. But with the bugs and crashes, this game is a dislike from me.The crashes happen at random times, and it's annoying if you haven't recently saved the game, as you'll have to repeat again to the spot where you was when it crashed. When you go down, both AI try and help you, therefor drawing the attention of enemies to the reviver, and getting knocked down while being revived. Terrible AI, they cannot navigate very well.I'm on a low-end video card (Radeon R7 240 2GB) and I can run this on Max settings, including Motion Blur, etc at 1600x1200 with decent fps. The mouse movement is terrible, it's jaggy and I can't spin/turn fast without getting confused.It can get repetitive, but at times you forget it's getting repetitive and continue.Gameplay 7.2/10Stability (Bugs & Crashes) 3/10AI 4/10

												Absolute dreck. Repetitive, average hack-n-slash gameplay, unfair checkpoints, bad-barebones dialogue; on top of that, the game suffers from MAJOR technical issues: this game keeps crashing to desktop and features poor graphics, it's basically UNPLAYABLE if you don't downgrade your video card controllers, but I refuse to go that far, because this is such a boring, unremarkable/unimportant game; a complete mess and one of the biggest disappoinments I've ever experienced: I was looking for a good LOTR game but instead I threw away some good money FOR NOTHING. I'd give it a 2,5/5 stars if the game was actually playable; as it stands it's an insulting 0/0, in other words a BIG NOTHING.

content:
30, 2016
												Starts off nice and hack and slash, doesn't give you much variation in attack styles. Whichever character you pick you're still left either at the mercy of your cohorts to revive you or trying to revive them which during battle soon gets old. I've only had this on the drive for a couple of hours and already contemplating removing it. The difficulty is far too steep and there is no incentive to keep trying once you've started to shout expletives at the game. Shame because the graphics aren't bad who doesn't like the LOTR characters and world, if only they'd belended this one with Shadow of Mordor (which in my opinion lacked a variation in enemies despite being fun to play).

y 16, 2014
												This was a very enjoyable game to play with my friend, until the last level, at which point the walls flashed colors and I got disconnected and had to progress in single player, still fighting bugs and glitches. I beat the boss with him, and we started the next difficulty. A side quest glitched and we couldn't complete it, but mainly it went the same as before, with me struggling to checkpoint my way through to the final boss. On the third an final difficulty, however, I got more bugs than ever before, all ending in a whopping save glitch that returned me to halfway through the first playthrough. My friend is on the doorstep of the final boss on the highest difficulty, and while I should be there with him, I'm all the way back, more than half his level, unable to join him unless I wade through a see of bugs again. This game is so full of unfixed bugs it's ridiculous. It's a fun game, but not fun enough to play through again without my friend.2/10, would not buy again.

												I first bought this at Gamestop for my 360 to check it out and see if it was any good. I played previous SnowBlind games, but I'm not a Lord of the Rings fan at all. But what I played of the used copy convinced me to pay it forward so to speak. I went back to Gamestop and changed it in for a real copy and paid the exta money. I very much enjoyed the game when I played it on the 360. I thought the combat was fun as well as the archery. I don't play the mage class so I can't say anything about that. I enjoy open world games the best. Like The Elder Scrolls and Grand Theft Auto. Fallout and what not. This game gives a slight feeling of open world but it does give you direction. And people will like that also. Not knowing what to do in a game is not fun.The difficulty seems fair. I'm not that great at video games, and found normal a fun, fair challenge.I will soon find out if the xbox 360 controller works for this game. The controller worked fine! Nice.So this is the 2nd time buying this game. Even though I played it twice on the 360. Warrior and Rouge class. Very fun.I played co op with my cousin on Xbox Live. I think we played through the whole game. But I can't remember for sure. Very fun game to play with a friend.It's fun co op or single player! I would give this game a try, It is not a masterpiece. The story pulled me in, even though I'm not a fan, and with the combination of great gameplay equals a great adventure!

8, 2015
												Very fun and  well written game that unfortunately suffers from horrid engine programming. Even with the best CPU and/or graphics card in your system, there are parts of this game that will slowly gobble up your system resources like your fat uncle on Thanksgiving! CPU usage will max out in graphics-intense areas while GPU won't be utilized properly, you'll suffer from crashes, and nearly unplayable spots. It's really a shame the engine doesn't perform better, because the gameplay and writing are great.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
9, 2015
												WotN is a basic action-rpg, with simple mechanics. My friends and I got this game for the coop (which is basically the only reason why this game is played).The game has lots of flaws: combat is repetitive (but somehow fun), skilltrees lack coherence, graphics are pretty bad, levels are poorly designed and full of invisible walls, and dialogues are a pain to hear.However, War in the North isn't a bad game: coop really is fun, and I could recommend it for coop games with friends, but let me tell why I won't: this game is the buggiest I've ever seen, really.First, enemy animations are broken in multiplayer. It's not a big deal during combat but it can break immersion. Random disconnects often occur; when they happen, the only thing you can do is rehosting the game, hoping your progression since the last checkpoints has been saved. Because, yes, this game has no manual save and you have to rely on autosave, which sometimes make you lose your experience and items, for whatever reason.Optimization is pretty bad. Graphics are ugly, but I still had unstable framerate, visual glitchs (like the white blinking screen which, as a bonus, gives headaches), and random freezes/stuttering. I don't have an AMD card, but I also read on the internet that some areas are unplayable for AMD users. Some players also reported that some visual glitches corrupted their drivers and they had to reinstall them.Also, if you communicate with Skype during gaming, the game may cause heavy lag on Skype. I don't know how, why, but it happens.My friends and I struggled with all those bugs and others for hours. Then the game caused a blue screen on the host's computer; it was the last straw, and we decided to quit playing this game.I wish this game was better, or at least, free of game-breaking bugs. I'm a huge Tolkien fan, and I'd like to say I loved this game and I recommend it, but this game is a scam, really. Don't buy it, you'll regret it.

content:
ry 15
												I've played this game together with a friend. It took us around 15 hours to finish the missions. The game was incredibly enjoyable for as long as it lasted, but 15 minutes of gameplay is not worth the price. The dialogues are a bit stale, as are the faces of the characters. At a certain moment, two brothers come and help you, whose sprites are litterally the same. They're like clones O_o. The hack and slash element of the game and the challenges of defeating strong foes are VERY enjoyable, however. It'd be great if there was a seperate 'open world' part of this game, so that the content would last more than 15 hours. (we were offered to do exactly the same missions on a harder game mode, but that's just meh). If you are looking for a fantasy game that you can play together with 1 or 2 mates, I'd recommend it. Otherwise, it's not worth the cash.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 17
												Bite Size Review - Lord of the Rings: War in the NorthThe Good:+ The dialoge and lore that characters have and speak to you about+ You can play as one of three unique classes + Story is interesting+ Graphics are on the old side, but still look ok+ Lots of loot+ You get to meet several characters from the film and they actually have a good amount to say and it is interesting+ Gameplay is simple but can still hold upThe Bad:- This is kind of a dealbreaker, I have a modern PC (runs New Doom 2016 on Highest settings etc) and this game slows down and crashes more times than is acceptableThe Verdict:So I just finished playing this game, and I have to say it was fun. You get to see some new places and some familar ones from the movies. You also get to meet and actually have meaningful conversations with characters from the movies and they actually talk a decent amount, it was really interesting to talk to them and learn more about the LotR universe. So I would classify this game as an average action role playing game, with great lore. All good stuff.Unfortunatly this is where I must tell you that this game crashed on me probably every 30 - 40 minutes and slowdowns in certain areas for no reason I could figure out. I just got a new computer recently, it runs the new doom at max settings 60 fps - now granted, I did switch to an AMD graphics card this time around (not Nvidia) so this may have something to do with it, or it may be windows 10, I am not sure. I tried to fix the usual ways I tend to fix these issues with other older games like using compatability modes etc. this but was unsucessful, forcing me to restart the game and just try to force my way through the crashy bits. But yeah, with the technical problems I ran into... even with the fun I had with the game, I can not recommend it. If it did not have these technical issues I could definitely recommend the game though for the lore, I really enjoyed that part of this game a lot. But with it's tachnical issues I will say "buyer beware" and leave it at that.

												   This is one of the CRASHIEST games I have ever played. The gameplay is not incredibly outstanding but its fun, until it CRASHES. The story is almost compleately unrelated to the movies or books (which I consider a good thing since most people have seen the movies or read the books) and is therefore mostly original yet still feels like lord of the rings, so its entertaining despite being brokeden up by regular CRASHES. The levels look like they might be fun to explore, at least once with each character, if I wasn't in a hurry to make it to the next save point before the inevitable CRASH. Its fun to walk around framiliar locations and talk to characters from the original story (books/movies) aften learning new things I didn't know before (that may or may not be canon), that is until... you guesed it: a CRASH.    Overall I am not dissapointed with my perchase, but I got it on sale for $4.99 or something and can not recomend it unless it is on sale (or they fix the crash issue).

												I started playing this game with very low expectations. It didn’t seem all that impressive from the trailers so I just said to myself: “Yet another one of EA’s attempts to milk the Lord of the Rings cash cow.”A couple of hours of hacking orcs with a friend changed my view of the game drastically. The first and most important thing you should know about the game is this: Do NOT expect a fun solo experience. This game is meant to be played with a friend or if at all possible, two.It is at its best when you are communicating with your friends in order to take down tough enemy groups and help each other survive difficult encounters.A lot of people are complaining about the simplicity of its design, but honestly, that’s what makes it work so well. The combat is straightforward and impactful (I suggest a gamepad but mouse and keyboard controls work well also) and the looting is surprisingly fun.War in the North won’t make you care too much about its story though. It isn’t very memorable or interesting in any way for that matter. This could have been improved upon by having the player actually make meaningful decisions. Unfortunately, the dialogue options seem to be there just to give you a little more information if you really want it.From a graphical point of view, the game is quite ok. You won’t be amazed by it, but occasionally, you might find yourself nodding to a slow motion decapitation or some other small detail (like how the snow sticks you your armor after you roll through it).This is indeed the grittiest Lord of the Rings game released and it feels great. If you wanted a more mature and accurate video game based on Tolkien’s books, this might be your thing.The sound is so and so. The music is great as always but the voice acting really put me to sleep. The greatest thing about it is the built in voice chant. It actually takes into account things like the distance between characters and the environment. For example, if a friend is in a cave and talks to me, his voice will have an echo. (I don’t think I’ve ever encountered a game with a similar feature)Is it a good game? Hell yeah! If you are a fan of co-op games, it will be hard to be disappointed with War in the North.I'd say an 8 out of 10 would be the grade. Not that it matters.

content:
er 22, 2013
												[STORY]✮✮✮✰✰ [GAMEPLAY]✮✮✮✰✰[REPLAYABILITY]✮✮✰✰✰[GAMEPLAY HOURS]6+ (Potentially 10+ to complete the entire story)"Lord of the Rings: War in the North is an action RPG that takes place alongside the story of the LOTR Trilogy. You can choose from three distinct characters to play as: Farin, the dwarf champion, Eradan, the human ranger, or Andriel, the elf mage. Each of these characters has their own unique fighting style and can attack both in melee and ranged. The game features a stat and skill system not unlike the Mass Effect series where you can upgrade certain abilities to your own preferred style of combat. The story puts you in pursuit of Agandaur, dark lord servant of Sauron, whose efforts may hinder the quest of the Fellowship of the Ring. In the game, you travel from notable locales from the books such as Bree, Sam Ford, and even the troll infested Etternmoors.The combat in this game feels very clunky and tiresome as combat abilities are restricted by both power cost and a cooldown timer. You certainly look heroic and cinematic as the animations of each sword swing and spell resemble that of the films, but the praise stops there. Alternating between 2-3 buttons, the combat feels repetitive and dull after the first few hours. Gameplay primarily consists of traveling from one zone to the next, defeating waves of enemies within a mostly linear path from objective to objective.War in the North features multiplayer, which may make the overall experience more enjoyable to some players. However, from a solo player standpoint, this game feels very grindy and ultimately not worth the frustration/boredom to continue playing simply to progress the plot."

content:
10, 2014
												Performance of the game:This game is a buggy mess.  I powered through a very bad bug in chapter 2 of the game that would have it randomly crash, took about 3 hours to pass a single section that should of took about 20 minutes, twice crashing seconds before triggering the saving in the game.  Most of the times it crashes it doesn't crash to desktop it blue screens my computer most of the time not giving a reason just something failed and the memory address of all “0”s and an x or 5 thrown in.  I have made it through chapter 7 with it crashing about every half hour and now in chapter 8 of the game I found another section that will crash every few minutes similar to chapter 2 of the game.  Now I have to quit.  The actual review of the game (based on when it is not crashing)one of the first things you get is a bird friend and you hit the 4 button to call for his aid.  Well the Elf character has a power that has you block and hit 4 (holding CTRL then hit 4).  even though the 4 icon has changed from the bird logo to a different logo, BOTH powers are used; the bird and area heal.  I wasted a lot of bird power trying to keep the other 2 friends alive.  Defense missions are the worst part, it goes fine until the enemy brings in the giant troll and he walk past you not caring that you are attacking him and then kills the thing you are protecting in 15 seconds.  I personally am more of a dodger power and like to dodge and not much blocking, I would of liked a double dodge (I only played the elf so I do not know if the other characters have a double dodge).  After facing a double sword enemy who is stabbing you so much that you can not dodge, I have learned to block against them just be for they attack and then attack them back.  Dialog was interesting even had a few points that you could try to tell some one that we are just passing through this very remote area to get to grandma's house (not exactly G ma’s house, but you are lieing about what you are doing so I thought it appropriate) and the NPC has non of that, but a very interesting choice to tell them.  Also there is a lot of repeat dialog choices that are represented as new choices.  Example: someone tells you of a castle; new option of the castle in dialog choices, npc just repeats the thing that brought up the new choice.  Combat was fun and interesting, slowly adding in new enemies over the 6 chapter's I played.  I would of loved to see how the ending turned out and if they kept adding new enemies through the end, but sadly the bugs and crashing my computer is enough to make me stop.

content:
er 25, 2013
												I got hold of this game in the one of the recent humblebundles. The game wasn't so bad in the beginning. Co-op is realy fun if you grab two friends and discover the world together. The item and skill/spell system is similar to many other RPGs nothing special  here.The quests are shallow and very easily completed (bring me A, find and rescue B, talk to C and tell her that i love her... bleh)Levels are tube-like and will not even alter in the slightest ways if you replay them.On easy/norm your two companions will almost everytime revive you from the "dead" if you fall,  making  it impossible to die ere. On heroic/legendary they will almost always die themselves, i'd recommend you to  play  with friends  here.Stil, the game seems technically unfinished for some reasons- You can't turn off the ingame voice manually, so when you're used  to play  with teamspeak, vent or skype you have to turn this  off instead of the ingame voice which btw has a  horrible delay- About half of the PC users experience heavy  graphic problems. Minor ones in level 2 and to a point unplayable ones in level 8. Either your game will shut down or sometimes you end up in blue screen. I only got past this level by drawing my bow, zooming in and look on the ground. This prevented me from seeing the graphic bugs all over  and  my game from shutting down every 15 seconds - this issue has been out there from the release of this game. It has not gotten  any updates so far and i doubt it will ever. That's a cruel statement of the developers. They don't even care.All in all i had a couple of great hours, but i was glad when i finally got my 46th achievement, closed the game, clicked on "delete local content" and will never play this  game again.

content:
er 30, 2013
												Gameplay itself is actually quite fun in co-op and the story is interesting (if not a little cliched), especially if you're a Tolkien fan. That said, there's several annoying bugs to be wary of. The game forces you to use Steam Voice in co-op, which is counter-intuitive in the likely scenario that you're already using a better form of voice communication. The game crashes frequently in graphically intensive situations, and this is a commonly reported issue for AMD card owners with post-HD5k era GPUs. The aggregate score of 66 seems fitting, as those looking for this type of game should enjoy it if they're willing to tolerate its issues. Get it when it's on sale.

content:
4, 2015
												Lord of the Rings: War in the North is a hack-and-slash game. That's... it.You control one of three characters with no personality or character development trying to chain as many finishers as possible, until you unlock Farin's Explosive Arrow and trivialize the game. Even the only vaguely challenging sections, which are the optional horde challenge maps. Along the way you will meet other fan-favorite characters such as the Fellowship, but then you will discover they have about as much relevance to you as this game does to Tolkein's legendarium. Sorry, Lord of the Rings fans.Your mission is to go kill the leader of Sauron's forces in the North, Agandaur. He is pathetically easy, but it's worth it (?) to see the CGI animation that probably ate up 70% of the budget for this game.The only way this game becomes decent is if you somehow game one, preferably two, friends into playing it with you. The time commitment shouldn't be that bad because the game is both easy and short. Playing with friends helps disguise some of the game's more egregious single-player faults, such as an incredibly limited inventory system, no ability to switch between characters on the fly (this requires you to completely reload the game), and the fact that some parts of the game are straight-up inaccessible without two or more players.Fortunately the game isn't super glitchy (there are some glitches but reloading usually fixes it) or unplayable, and you'll probably unlock 95% of the achievements without even trying.Sadly, War in the North failed to live up to any of its promise. It's not a HORRIBLE game by any means, but there are way better uses of your time.
